unnormalised: ## My Marks: A Comedy in Multiple Acts (or Should I Say, Semesters?)
normalised: ## My Marks: A Comedy in Multiple Acts (or Should I Say, Semesters?)

unnormalised: Ah, exam results. That time of year when students across India collectively hold their breath, clutching their hall tickets like they're winning lottery tickets (spoiler alert: most of us aren't). As someone who's seen my fair share of academic ups and downs, I thought I'd share some hilarious (in hindsight) moments from my own journey.
normalised: Ah, exam results. That time of year when students across India collectively hold their breath, clutching their hall tickets like they are winning lottery tickets (spoiler alert: most of us are not). As someone who has seen my fair share of academic ups and downs, I thought I would share some hilarious (in hindsight) moments from my own journey.

unnormalised: Let's rewind to my 10th standard results. The internet was slow, the anxiety was high, and the website kept crashing. After 27 attempts (yes, I counted), I finally saw my marks: 65% overall. My reaction? A mix of relief and slight disappointment. My mom, bless her heart, said, "Beta, first division toh aa gaya!" (At least you got a first division!). My dad, ever the practical one, immediately started calculating my potential career options based on that percentage. Apparently, becoming an astronaut was off the table.
normalised: Let us rewind to my tenth standard results. The internet was slow, the anxiety was high, and the website kept crashing. After twenty seven attempts (yes, I counted), I finally saw my marks: sixty five percent overall. My reaction? A mix of relief and slight disappointment. My mom, bless her heart, said, "Beta, first division toh aa gaya!" (At least you got a first division!). My dad, ever the practical one, immediately started calculating my potential career options based on that percentage. Apparently, becoming an astronaut was off the table.

unnormalised: Then came the infamous 12th grade. The pressure was immense. Everyone was aiming for 90%+, dreaming of IITs and AIIMS. I, on the other hand, was aiming for… passing. My physics paper was a disaster. I swear, I spent more time drawing diagrams of circuits than actually understanding them. Result? A glorious 50 marks. Just enough to save my overall percentage (72%) and keep my engineering dreams alive.

unnormalised: And oh, engineering college! A whole new level of academic chaos. We had subjects like "Engineering Thermodynamics" (which, to this day, I can't explain) and "Data Structures and Algorithms" (which sounds cool but mostly involved staring at code until 3 AM). My first semester GPA was a respectable 7.5, which I proudly announced to my family. They were less impressed when they found out that anything above 7 was considered decent.

My first semester G-P-A was a respectable seven point five, which I proudly announced to my family. They were less impressed when they found out that anything above seven was considered decent.

unnormalised: One particular exam stands out in my memory: "Signals and Systems." I had barely attended any classes and crammed the entire syllabus the night before. The result was a complete catastrophe. I scored a whopping 32 out of 100. My professor, a kind soul, actually looked concerned. He suggested I attend his extra classes. I politely declined, knowing that more classes wouldn't magically make me understand Fourier transforms.

unnormalised: But here's the thing: even though my marks weren't always stellar, I learned a lot along the way. I learned how to manage my time (or, more accurately, how to procrastinate effectively). I learned how to collaborate with my classmates (mostly for assignments, let's be honest). And I learned that a number on a marksheet doesn't define your worth.

unnormalised: Speaking of numbers, there was that one time in my 3rd year when I accidentally added my marks wrong on my internal assessment form. I inflated my score by 10 marks! The professor noticed, of course, and gave me a look that could curdle milk. I sheepishly corrected it, and he gave me a lecture about honesty and the importance of double-checking your work. Lesson learned!

unnormalised: So, to all the students anxiously awaiting their results: Don't let the numbers dictate your happiness. Whether you score 99% or 40%, remember that this is just one chapter in your life. There are many more exams, interviews, and challenges ahead. And who knows, maybe one day you'll look back at your marks and laugh, just like I do.
